ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: French 140 has an awkward goal for a language class: because most students have nearly reached fluency, the emphasis on grammar sometimes feels inane. It's tough and time-consuming, but in a busywork kind of way. The emphasis on compositions and conversations ensures that students will be challenged in a compelling way.

Yes! The class is more laid-back than french l1 and l2 here. The class is geared towards improving oral and reading comprehension and thinking in french. i.e. redactions were graded a lot on content. and we read a lot of short stories, two novels and watched some movies.work load: a few pages of course packet per night. A decent amount of reading each week. 5 redactions and tests.
Yes. Very helpful in developing your french.

This is a very good class. There was a heavy emphasis on speaking and listening comprehension (as well as reading comprehension). Sometimes the grammar could get a bit tedious. Fren 140 is very work intensive- I found myself spending 1.5-2 hours a night on homework. There were four unit tests, four essays (the last one was in-class), and a final exam.

A conversation-oriented language class that focuses discussion on a few different texts. The texts are generally interesting and expose students to different francophone cultures.I don't know that I'd really recommend the course, because I feel there wasn't most improvement for most students.
Pretty easy step from L3 to L4, maybe too easy. The hw takes a long time and some of it seems like busy work. I recommend Proffesor Koundi.
